trial_identification.studytitle: A study of the EpiSure syringe vs conventional epidural syringe
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Comparison of the EpiSure Autodetect syringe with the conventional loss-of-resistance syringe among parturients in labour: a randomised controlled trial of analgesic proficiency

conditions.healthcondition: Failure of epidural analgesia for labour

interventions.interventions: EpiSure syringe (Indigo Orb, Irvine, CA), a novel spring-loaded epidural syringe for detecting loss-of-resistance to saline during epidural insertion. The syringe is used to locate the epidural space during epidural insertion, and contains up to 6 ml of 0.9% saline.
interventions.comparator: Conventional Portex syringe (Smiths Medical ASD, Keene, NH) used for epidural insertion using loss-of-resistance to saline. The syringe is used to locate the epidural space during epidural insertion, and can hold up to 10 ml of 0.9% saline.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Failure to provide adequate analgesia, as determined by assessment of epidural blockade using ice packs, and numeric rating score for pain
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Effectiveness of pain relief 20 minutes after epidural analgesia

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Incidence of successful epidural insertion with one pass of the epidural needle
Number of attempts to locate epidural space
Time taken to locate epidural space

Incidence of failed analgesia (i.e. no change in pain or worsening pain, with no change in sensation to cold stimulus) as determined by numerical rating score of pain and epidural block assessment with ice pack
Incidence of inadvertent dural puncture as determined by patient history and examination
Incidence of entry into an epidural vein as determined by aspiration of blood from the epidural catheter
Anaesthetists' assessment of the EpiSure syringe determined using brief questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At conclusion of study (either at the end of the anaesthetists participation in the study, such as when they leave this institution, or once all patients have been recruited)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Incidence of localised back pain at epidural site as determined by numeric rating score for pain

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Epidural analgesia for labour American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Classification I to III patients
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Combined spinal and epidural Fetal abnormality Contraindication to epidural analgesia Spinal abnormaility Body mass index (BMI) above 44

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: King Edward Memorial Hospital for Women

fundingsource.fundingname: Abbott/ASA (Australian Society of Anaesthetists) Research Grant
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Australian Society of Anaesthetists Suite 603 Eastpoint Tower 180 Ocean Street Edgecliff NSW 2027

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
We intend to evaluate the EpiSure, a new epidural syringe that uses a novel spring-loaded mechanism to locate the correct place in the back for epidural insertion. Early data regarding this device suggests that it may ease the process of inserting an epidural and reduce complications, particularly in anaesthetists who are relatively new to the procedure of epidural insertion.
We will compare effectiveness of pain relief and outcomes in patients whose epidurals are inserted with the EpiSure with those whose epidurals are inserted with traditional syringes.
